renamed. @fjy

@gianm Using first/last aggregator at ingestion time is kind of tricky with the value we want to store. Ideally, we want to persist the first and last metric as long/double column so other aggregator such as sum can aggregate them. However, doing so would cause merging persisted data to be incorrect since no time value are stored for the metric. If the values are instead stored as time value pair, the column could not be aggregated by standard aggregators. Basically the problem is that we want an intermediate storage format for merging and a different final storage format for querying, and this cannot be done in the ingestion process. Now I‚Äôll just leave the comment in aggregations.md that first/last aggregators can't be used at ingestion time.

It seems that there are very little shared code between long and double type aggregator, so I changed the syntax to be the same with max, min, and sum with doubleFirst/Last and longFirst/Last in the newer commit.

We've upgraded to 0.9.1.1 and also seeing what looks like this issue. :cry:
@fjy sure I'll take a look at this today

So this is a potentially severe problem for us, we're attempting to launch a beta in the next couple of weeks and were counting on this bug to be fixed in order to use Select queries to drive one of our key features. But I think we've got a work around. I'll describe it here and would welcome comments on feasibility and any performance impacts.

We have a page in our application that is populated via Select queries, routing through a middle tier service that handles the actual queries. We return a page of data and then have an "infinite scroll" type UI to fetch additional pages. this works by having the service return with each response the pagingIdentifier to be used to fetch the next page. So when the infinite scroll is triggered, it sends another request including the pagingIdentifier it received with the last response. The service can then use that to query for the next page.

(By the way, this setup has another problem in addition to the current bug - if the matching data is sparse and a page spans many segments, the full map of pagingIdentifiers can reach into dozens of segments, enough to bust the limit on URL length when they are included as a query parameter. The following workaround addresses that issue too.)

The work around is to take the pagingIdentifiers returned by Druid and strip them down to only the last (latest) segment. That is returned to the web app, which includes it in the request for the next page just like the current implementation. But when the service receives that request, it parses out the starting time of the segment and uses that as the start date on the interval for the query. This seems to be working based on some cursory adhoc tests.

E.g.:

Druid returns `pagingIdentifiers`:

``` javascript
{
'11_schema_2016-07-25T07:00:00.000Z_2016-07-26T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-25T21:39:13.302Z': 1899, 
'11_schema_2016-07-26T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-27T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-25T21:39:13.302Z': 201
}
```

We return, as the "next page" parameter, only the last of these entries (with the offset incremented per usual): 

``` javascript
{
'11_schema_2016-07-26T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-27T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-25T21:39:13.302Z': 202
}
```

When that gets returned in the request for the next page, we parse out `2016-07-26T00:00:00.000` from the segment name and set that as the lower bound on our query interval :

``` javascript
{
  "queryType": "select", 
  "intervals": [ "2016-07-26T00:00:00.000/<...>"],
  "pagingSpec": { "pagingIdentifiers" : {"11_schema_2016-07-26T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-27T00:00:00.000Z_2016-07-25T21:39:13.302Z": 202 } , "threshold" : "<...>"}
}
```

As I say, this seems to solve the problem (but we haven't tested it thoroughly yet).
note, #3270 will result in extensibility for StringComparator.

Perhaps it would be better for `VersionedIntervalTimeline.lookup` to return a snapshot using ImmutablePartitionHolders (like findEntry does). That way callers don't have to worry about their looked-up timelines being wibbly-wobbly.

@ryryguy  - i had to do the same thing  (thanks for taking the time to explain the solution in detail for my case - i ran a bunch of tests yesterday - did not update this thread) - the way i understood it is it returns another segment if there's no more of a previous segment - but the way the data is structured for pagingIdentifiers , I was not sure if there would be ever more than 2 keys inside pagingIdentifiers? The docs probably should be updated with an example of such (2 identifiers returned) and perhaps someone here from the druid / metamx team confirm if there would ever be more than 2 keys returned inside pagingIdentifiers.

Agree, I modified the fix to obtain a new  copy of PartitionHolder instead. @gianm 
Changing to ImmutablePartitionHolders can't pass the old unit test, so I just simply change to `new PartitionHolder<ObjectType>(val.getPartitionHolder())` which means the same thing.

However, the overlord was showing the middle managers as having all slots but one available (there was one task in a running state even though it did not have a peon process), which is why it was so odd that the other task ended up in a pending state.  I do not recall exactly what happened on a restart of the overlord other than it didn't change my final state - sorry I don't remember if it created new tasks or not.  If this happens again I will make sure to save the logs.

@navis I think the mechanism from #3270 should allow a custom StringComparator to be specified like `"ordering" : {"type":"myComparator"}` if it's registered as a subtype. `"ordering" : "myComparator"` would not work, that'd only be for the "built-in" comparators, but I think that's fine?

Behavior here is similar to QueryGranularity, where `"hour"` and `{"type" : "duration", "duration" : 3600000 }` are equivalent.
transient failure, bouncing.
looks good, with one comment.

@KenjiTakahashi, thanks for posting your experience.

From my perspective the problems you pointed out mostly come from the fan out to the processing pool on historicals. Most Druid queries work this way because it works well for aggregations that can be parallelized¬†and then merged. But Select doesn't really work well with the parallelize-then-merge strategy due to the threshold, the ordering restriction, and the lack of aggregation. It really begs for something more like "continuous merge". Maybe it would be better for Select to run single threaded.
ugh, yeah... that needs to be fixed by making it configurable in http-client

Added the helper class RowBasedGrouperHelper for some common code between RowProcessor and GroupByMergingQueryRunnerV2. The main common thing between these two classes is that they both aggregate on row sequence using the same grouping and spilling mechanism. The helper class include function to create the grouper and accumulator, and make row iterator from grouper.

I can see some more `new TimelineObjectHolder()` in the class, like line of 244, 471, 483. Is it ok?

@navis the others in `lookup` (471, 483) I think are okay, since they re-use safe copies already created (not going back to original objects).

There's another one in `findOvershadowed` (244). I don't think that one causes bugs in production, because it's only used in one place (DruidCoordinatorCleanupOvershadowed), which doesn't do multithreaded writes. But it does look suspicious and might cause problems if it's used for other stuff in the future‚Ä¶ it could be made into a copy too, to be safe.

My feeling is that this is a neat feature but would better belong in the ToolChests (probably in `postMergeQueryDecoration`) than in a post processing operator. That way it would be extensible for custom queries.
